title: Why 72, exactly?
content:
Does anyone know what's so special about 72 dots per inch on the Web? Does it have anything to do with 12 points per pica, six picas per inch? Or is it a myth?   
   
A colleague claims that Web graphics must be saved at 72 DPI. But in my experience, only pixels matter, unless you want more work for yourself. I've tried it with several browsers on Mac and Windows... but 300x200 pixels is 300x200 pixels at 2 dpi and 2000 dpi.   
   
Thanks,   
Ben
author: benthinkin

comments.content:
Well, it has to do with the resolution of your monitor. Almost every monitor's resolution is 72 DPI. If you save at anything higher for web usage, you are making the file unnecessarily larger.   
(Unless you have [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141429/http:/www-132.ibm.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/ProductDisplay?catalogId=-840&langId=-1&partNumber=9503DG5&storeId=1) thing)

Ben's right. It's meaningless. On the Web, everything\* is pixels, and images are either displayed automatically at their full resolution, or at a specified resolution in pixels. The DPI is irrelevant.   
   
T   
   
\* Everything meaning all bitmap graphics displayed in native Web formats such as JPEG and GIF. There are of course vector and proprietary formats as well.

_Almost every monitor's resolution is 72 DPI._   
   
Wrong. Almost every _Mac_ monitor is 72 dpi, but what's that? Less that 5% of the market? Most Wintel monitors have had a real resolution of 96 dpi for years now, and most new flat screens are 122 dpi or higher. Mine is 133 dpi; my business partner's is 145 dpi; some of my clients have IBM 200 dpi screens. Only Apple are still largely stuck at 72 dpi.

Actually, the assertion that mac screens are 72dpi is also not _quite_ correct either. The operating system renders type at a nominal resolution of 72dpi, but how its actually displayed on a particular monitor is up to the monitor's size and pixel resolution.   
   
Its an easy thing to prove too - just set your monitor's resolution to a different one than it is currently working at and the actual resolution of it in DPI will change, but the nominal resolution that the OS is drawing graphics at will remain at 72dpi on a mac or 96dpi (or whatever) on a Windows box.   
   
DPI is, as fellow hairyface Thomas said, irrelevant.

at a specified resolution in pixels. The DPI is irrelevant._      
   
Not only that, but the GIF format, which was created specifically for   
Internet use, doesn't even store resolution info in the image file.   
The 72 dpi thing is just a default it's opened at.   
   
And Ben, yes, the rationale behind the 72 dpi nominal resolution on   
the Mac was that one screen pixel would equal one "pica" point.

The orignal macs were 72 ppi (pixels per inch). The original laserwriters were 144 dpi. Twice that of the screen. It was built that way since the mac was a 'graphics' computer from the onset.   
   
However, as other's have stated, it's been a long time since a monitor was actually 72ppi. However, screen resolution certainly has not increased exponentially as much as HD space and Processor speeds have. We're still stuck with monitors that are under 150 ppi for the most part.

The original ImageWriter was 144 dpi; the original LaserWriter was 300 dpi.   
   
I seem to recall some sort of fudge factor switch one could use to make bitmap fonts print better on the LaserWriter, which had to do with 288 dpi being an even multiple of 72. Was it that one could choose to print at 288/300 of nominal size, which would be 96%?   
   
T

Further to my last post: I think that was a switch that made screen-res bitmaps in general print better, not only bitmap fonts.

Where did 72 dots in an inch originate anyway? 72 seems like a very arbitrary number, and for it to have carried over into the digital age is simply because of tradition.

But the font needed to have the double-size bitmap available in the OS. The olden days indeed.

Chris, 72 isn't arbitrary, it's 12 x 6, and 12 has been a cornerstone number since ancient times. The king of Thailand (Rama IX) had his 60th (12 x 5) birthday a couple of years ago, an it was a big deal. Even I had to show up (that's a joke).   
   
hhp

Here's one good reason: It makes it easier to do the math.   
   
72 has a lot of numbers which can be divided into it evenly:   
2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 12, 18, 24, and 36. Notice anything   
interesting about those numbers? Most of them are   
standard type sizes. It made it easy to figure out how many   
lines fit into an inch with standard type sizes. Even better,   
many of the standard sizes divide evenly into one another   
by a factor of 2 or 3. Some standard type sizes are odd (10,   
11, 14, 30, 60) or only come out even every 2 inches (48),   
but not as many as there would be if a different number   
had been chosen.   
   
Try doing the same thing with 50, 75, or 100. With 50 you   
get 2, 5, 10, and 25. 75 gets you 3, 5, 15, and 25. 100 gets   
you 2, 5, 10, 20, 25, and 50.   
   
Since we use computers to do all our math now, convenient   
numbers like 72 are little more than historical habits, but   
it's not hard to see why they were chosen in the metal type   
days.

Hrant, I remember the technique he's referring to. The   
problem was that when you printed 72dpi graphics on a   
300dpi laser printer, the low-res pixels would come out   
uneven creating a kind of moirï¿½ pattern. By reducing the   
page to 96%, the pixels would all line up perfectly with the   
300dpi dots of the printer. In effect, you converted the   
graphic to 75dpi, exactly 4x4 dots per pixel.
